Comment: The signature move of the Noteboom Variation, also sometimes referred to as the Stolen Pawn.  Black grabs a pawn at the expense of development and the usual complications ensue.  The opening isn't seen that often so White probably has the better of it, but it has some surprise value (if there is such a thing in correspondence chess).

Fritz wants 53.. Kf7, and if 54 Rd7  Kf6! when Black only temporarily goes down two pawns.  Ultimately White would be left with a useless rook pawn, but I missed all that.

Fritz says White can press on for a win with 54 Rd7.  Luckily for me it wasn't too clear at the board.  White instead offers an exchange, perhaps not realizing that Black's king holds the opposition in the pawn ending.

One square makes a world of difference here.  If instead 57.. Kf8?? 58 Kf6 and Black's king has lost the opposition and the game.  I was once on the winning end of such a mistake made by an A-player short on time in an O.T.B. game.  In correspondence these things are easier.
